subject: Plax to Prison
event:
So Plaxico Burress has agreed to a plea bargain, and will be going to prison for two years for sticking a loaded pistol in his sweatpants, taking it to a crowded nightclub, and shooting himself in the thigh.  He also lost something like $27 million when the Giants dropped him, and may have lost his NFL career as well.  He will be 34 when he gets out.

I don't quarrel with the sentence.  Plax was incredibly stupid, and he broke the law.

But our justice system does seem seriously out of whack.  Plax gets two years for carrying a concealed weapon and accidentally shooting himself, Michael Vick gets two years for dog fighting, and Donte Stallworth gets thirty days for driving drunk and killing a man.

If I were king, I would have sent all three to jail, but Stallworth would have gotten the longest sentence, and Plax the lightest.  Yes, Plax might have killed someone too, if the gun had gone off in the nightclub and the bullet had gone someplace other than his leg.  But, ah, it didn't.  We don't usually sentence people on the basis of what might have happened.  Donte Stallworth actually DID kill another human being, no "might have" or "could have" involved.

And on the same note, I think Ray Lewis should have gone to prison too.  Two people died that night, and I believe that Lewis knows who killed them, but won't say.

But there you go.  Sometimes I wish Justice would take off that blindfold.

comments.article: If I were king, I'd outlaw beets.
If that happened, my wife would lead a revolution.

If all of those crimes took place in the same jurisdiction you would have a stronger point. As it is, different locales weigh different crimes more heavily than others. For example- Plax didn't get 2 years for carrying a concealed weapon and accidentally shooting himself, he got 2 years for carrying an unlicensed weapon in New York. He could have had it openly strapped to his thigh. He could have intentionally shot himself, rather than accidentally. All of that is incidental to the fact that he ran afoul of the law prohibiting carrying an unlicensed gun in NY.

In another state? He wouldn't face 3.5 years mandatory, pled down to 2.

Donte Stallworth got 30 days, again due to many factors. He acknowledged responsibility, the family involved did not want to have a drawn-out fiasco, and so on. I agree that 30 days is light, but it is rather disingenuous to imply that it is the totality of his punishment.

This is why I draw a distinction between, say, Stallworth and Vick. Stallworth made a mistake - a stupid mistake, a horrible mistake, a mistake that cost a man his life and he will have to life with forever. He deserves more than 30 days in jail, and he deserves the yearlong suspension from the NFL. The difference between him and Vick (which many people seem unable to understand) is not that dogs are more important than people, but that Vick did not take responsibility for his actions, denied culpability until all of his compatriots turned on him, and did not make a one-time mistake, but rather continued the criminal acts for seven years.

I'm all over the place in this comment- and I'm sure some Eagles fan will come here and claim I'm not a real NFL fan. What I'm trying to get across is that the three players and their run-ins with the law cannot be compared equally, because they were in separate jurisdictions, which have different punishments for the same crimes, and some of them were the result of stupid, stupid mistakes and some of them were the result of deliberate, malicious, evil acts.
What you are describing looks more like reasons why "justice will inevitably be unfair, and this is a good thing" than any sort of reasoning for why this is fair (excepting that regarding Vick).

I think we should make him go to the Wall and wear the black.

Also known as "Play for the Raiders".

I had the EXACT same thought when I heard about Plax's sentence earlier today. How is it his sentence is so much longer than Donte's? Honestly, the embarrassment Plaxico must have felt, not to mention the pain of shooting your own thigh, seems almost enough of a punishment to me.

I hear you sir; I hear you.
... 'Nuf said' as a theologian of or time once wrote...
comments.subject: justice

comments.article: I totally agree with you! The Justice system can be ridiculously unfair.

I thought the blind part was supposed to be about the "person" [as in it matters not whether a prince or a pauper, the law is applied the same] but more and more it seems it sees the "person" just fine but not the act. And yes--all of it. Though maybe not the Ray Lewis part--I'm not sure material witnesses should be incarcerated.
I agree, definitely. Some sentences are just too lenient. And others are just ridiculous.

Ok, I have to say that first of all, people should really stop comparing the Michael Vick case and the Donte Stallworth case. The two have zero similarities to each other, and should not be compared and contrasted. Taken on their own merits, I think the sentencing in all of these cases is fair and justified. Regarding the Stallworth accident - it was not his fault. He was driving over the legal limit, but the DUI was not the cause of the accident. The victim was illegally trying to run across a 6-lane highway. The collision was not going to be avoided. Stallworth was cooperative and remorseful. It was a terrible accident, but it was an accident nonetheless, a one time thing that wasn't going to be avoided even if Stallworth's BAC was .000.

Mike Vick was the leader of an interstate, ongoing criminal enterprise, who showed zero remorse and did not cooperate with authorities at all. He exhibited a pattern of reprehensible behavior that would have been continuing on to this day had he not been caught. People like to say, "Stallworth killed a human, Vick only killed dogs." Well, that's not what Vick was sentenced for. It was for being head of a criminal gambling ring. And, as a side thought, who's to say that a human life is inherently more valuable than an animal's? We're all here trying to survive and make it to tomorrow.

Stallworth = 1 time accident. Vick = years of ongoing criminal activity. Burress = just plain dumb.
comments.subject: sigh...

comments.article: My god, there's someone else who thinks the same way as me. I could have written that post (and nearly did, above).
comments.subject: Re: sigh...

comments.article: Didn't Ted Kennedy drive drunk off a bridge and kill a woman and then flee the scene?  How much jail time did he get?  Our justice system is entrepreneurial at best.  At worst its just plain awful.
comments.subject: Unfair

comments.article:
I'm fine with Plax's prison sentence, it seems a little tough but New York is New York and they have their laws in place for a reason. I do agree that Donte' got off way too easy and as far as I'm concerned Vick should have been executed. there's your "monster of inhuman cruelty".

As for Ray Lewis... anybody who compares Steve McNair to Christ would probably be more at home in a nut farm than a prison.
comments.subject: Plax to prison

comments.article: We punish people for might-have-beens all the time. Attempted murder, attempted whatever. Gun laws are in place for some good reasons, one of which is to deter half-wits from carrying guns they have no idea how to use. Anyway, this is the make or break year for Eli. Even with his SB title, he still has alot of doubters. (including me) If he throws for 25+ TD's and leads the Giants to the playoffs again I'll eat my hat.

I was going to say something like this -- the guy who takes a gun into a nightclub and gets into trouble for doing so is getting into trouble on a "might-have-been". Same for DUIs who don't actually hurt anyone. Just because the protection against might-have-beens is somewhat abstracted into higher levels of law doesn't make it any less of a punishment for a potential for the guy.

That said I agree with you -- someone who DUIs (as I insinuated above, essentially carrying a loaded weapon,) and kills someone should get more time than someone who carries a loaded weapon and *doesn't* kill someone.
comments.subject: Re: ???????

comments.article:
"But our justice system does seem seriously out of whack. Plax gets two years for carrying a concealed weapon and accidentally shooting himself, Michael Vick gets two years for dog fighting, and Donte Stallworth gets thirty days for driving drunk and killing a man."

AMEN!
I am disguisted by the fact that Stallworoth is getting of so ridiculously light! The word "unfair" doesn't even begin to describe this bastardization of justice.
I completely agree with you.

"Yes, Plax might have killed someone too, if the gun had gone off in the nightclub and the bullet had gone someplace other than his leg. But, ah, it didn't. We don't usually sentence people on the basis of what might have happened."

I dunno, I think the heavy penalties for drunk driving are a perfect example of us sentencing people on the basis of what might have happened. Because moral luck is a crappy defense and once you get behind the wheel drunk you've decided you're cool with risking the lives of anyone you happen to come across while intoxicated. The action is morally identical, whether or not you get lucky and make it home without hitting someone.
I agree - I think drunk divers should simply lose their license (unless they hurt/kill someone while driving drunk)

you'd think as a multi-millionare this football player could have ... oh, i don't know, AFFORD TO BUY A HOLSTER and a BELT and some PANTS.

darwin at work.

You can't get rid of a belt and holster as easily as a pistol carried "Mexican".  People with concealed carry permits overwhelmingly use holsters, because in most jurisdictions nothing bad happens to them if a cop or other trained observer spots their gun. People who are carrying guns illegally, on the other hand, have a great incentive to be able to get rid of the gun without any obvious evidence that ties it to them.
comments.subject: Holster

comments.upictitle: OMG, it's a talking biscuit named Mara!: Nature-Redwood path
comments.article: You, dear sir, have said a mouthful. And then some.

If I were King, I would lock you in a tower cell with only bread and water until you finished "A Dance of Dragons".
But seriously, I have no idea about the cases you were mentioning cause I am from Germany but I do now that the law system in the USA is quite ridiculous. Actually I think it is one of the things that nearly every European is quite sure about but many Americans not because you life with it every day in your life and it so without really thinking about it, it seems normal to you. Fotunately there are always people who think.

P.S. I cant wait for the HBO Series, I hope I will have a chance to see that in Germany.

Florida should be absolutely ashamed at their laws, their legal system, and the lawyers and judges who permitted such a light sentence. It's absolutely disgusting that the commissioner of a sport would have a stiffer penalty for a crime involving a man's death.

I've been calling the toronto sports radio evey time they harp on Vick (absolutely disgusting what he did)...but they're crucifying him and barely even mentioned Stallworth. No one even mentioned Lewis and I had to say something....they just keep going on and on about Vick.

I agree with you but the general population here still seems to think Vick's the worst.

MADD should have a showdown with PETA....
comments.subject: You are so right

comments.article: Vick is worse.  Who would you rather have as your next door neighbor?
comments.subject: Re: You are so right

comments.article: Justice is a tricky thing. We want to see similar consequences for similar violations of the law...but in my humble opinion, true justice is dissimilar consequences for dissimilar violations. The Donte Stallworth situation cannot be summarily categorized as simply the "taking of a life." The taking of one life is not the same as the taking of another. Murder, manslaughter and causing a death while defending oneself are completely different things. Rightfully so, we punish the murderer the most...the involuntary manslaughterer the least...and the self-defender not at all. Stallworth was drinking that night...had a BAC of .126 and was speeding (50 in a 40). The person he hit was rushing to catch a bus after getting off of work and did not use a crosswalk, but ran through traffic. Stallworth saw him before he hit him...and even flashed his brights at him. Had Stallworth not been drinking that night...would he have still hit him? Maybe...maybe not. Was the drinking a contributing cause? Maybe...maybe not. Stallworth didn't flee the seen after the collision...called police...cooperated with authorities...and ultimately took responsibility for an accident that he may not have been the sole cause of. Was 25 days in jail...2 years of house arrest...8 years of supervised probation...an alcohol/drug evaluation & treatment....a lifetime drivers license revocation...and 1,000 hours of community service...an appropriate punishment for the situation? The prosecutor, the judge, the victim's family and the accused all thought so.  I guess I do as well.
comments.subject: I must disagree...

comments.article:
Exactly.

This is the best summary of the facts I've read on this blog. When you look at the actual facts of the case, it makes a lot of sense.

comments.subject: Bitter about 2000 Super Bowl?

comments.article: There is no justice ,only the law.

As another of my favorite authors said through one of his recurring charcters:
"Thre is no justice, just us."

Well, Lewis, at least, was actually found not guilty in a court of law if I remember right. You and I may think it likely that he got away with murder, but you can't send him to prison on inference of guilt for something that a jury found him not guilty of.

Agree that Stallworth should have gotten a longer sentence, even though the death seems likely to have not hinged on the alcohol, as driving drunk is not under any circumstances an oopsie. But there is also the distinction between what is intentional and what is not, and it is at least possible that Stallworth realized just too late the enormity of what he had done and was shocked straight by it; which is not likely the case with Vick, even though Vick's action, taken in a vacuum, is not as severe as Stallworth's in vacuo.

I watch two sports, boxing and the NFL. They are the two greatest spectator sports we have, in my opinion, and yet both have some of the worst of our society as athletes, management and promotion.

I heard a statistic on talk radio the other day, I don't know if it's true or not, that 21% of current NFL players have been convicted of some type of violent or drug/alcohol related crime. I mean, can you imagine how many get away with it or plea something, if that is the CONVICTION percentage? It's scary.

Like many have said, Michael Vick has a right to live his free life, but it's not a right to play in the NFL, it's a privilege, one he should no longer have, in my opinion.


http://nflcrimes.blogspot.com/

Sad. Very sad.
